etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in Thomas Pennant (1726–1798), naturalist, traveller, and writer. From French fossane, probably ultimately from Malagasy fosa + -ane, of uncertain origin

definitions: The Malagasy or striped civet, Fossa fossana (family Viverridae), a ground-living, genet-like carnivore endemic to Madagascar.

notes.text: The fossane and other Madagascan carnivores are now sometimes placed in a separate family, Eupleridae.
